definition[0]: used to refer to all the people or things in a particular group or all the parts of something
example[0]: We looked carefully at every car that drove past.
example[1]: Every child will receive a certificate at the end of the course.
example[2]: I enjoyed every minute of the film.
example[3]: I listened carefully to every word he said.
example[4]: He seems to know every single person in the school.
example[5]: They made us pick up every last scrap of paper.
definition[1]: used to say how often something happens
example[6]: Freda had to stop to rest every hundred metres or so  (=each time she had gone 100 metres).
example[7]: They see each other every day.
example[8]: Richard visits his mother every week.
example[9]: Re-apply your sunscreen every two hours.
definition[2]: used to say how much distance there is between the things in a line
example[10]: There were traffic lights every ten yards.
example[11]: We wish you every happiness in your new home.
example[12]: There is every chance that he will recover.
example[13]: We have every reason to believe that the operation will be a success.
example[14]: We have every intention of winning this competition.
explanation[0]: You use every with a singular noun and a singular verb
example[15]: Every person has the right to a fair trial
explanation[1]: Don’t use every with a plural noun
explanation[2]: You usually use ‘his’, ‘her’, ‘himself’, or ‘herself’ after every
example[17]: Every woman can speak for herself
explanation[3]: However, you can use ‘their’, ‘they’, ‘them’ etc when you do not want to say whether the people are male or female
example[18]: Every child has their own room
